text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

quote.#text: Director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology
Section 203(1) of the National Windstorm Impact Reduction Act of 2004

quote.#tail: means public works and utilities, including transportation facilities and infrastructure, oil and gas pipelines, electrical power and communication facilities and infrastructure, and water supply and sewage treatment facilities.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Section 204 of the National Windstorm Impact Reduction Act of 2004
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Windstorm Impact Reduction Act of 2004/s:204
National Windstorm Impact Reduction Act of 2004/s:204/ss:a
National Windstorm Impact Reduction Act of 2004/s:204/ss:b
National Windstorm Impact Reduction Act of 2004/s:204/ss:c

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , the purpose of which is to achieve major measurable reductions in the losses of life and property from windstorms through a coordinated Federal effort, in cooperation with other levels of government, academia, and the private sector, aimed at improving the understanding of windstorms and their impacts and developing and encouraging the implementation of cost-effective mitigation measures to reduce those impacts.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Windstorm Impact Reduction Program

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall have the primary responsibility for planning and coordinating the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: National Institute of Standards and Technology

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: . In carrying out this paragraph, the Director shall—
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Windstorm Impact Reduction Program

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: includes the necessary components to promote the implementation of windstorm risk reduction measures by Federal, State, and local governments, national standards and model building code organizations, architects and engineers, and others with a role in planning and constructing buildings and lifelines;
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Windstorm Impact Reduction Program

text.#text: support the development of performance-based engineering tools, and work with appropriate groups to promote the commercial application of such tools, including through wind-related model building codes, voluntary standards, and construction best practices;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: agencies, as necessary to assist in carrying out this Act;
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Windstorm Impact Reduction Program

text.#text: request the assistance of Federal agencies other than the
coordinate all Federal post-windstorm investigations; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: on the use of such recommendations.

text.#text: when warranted by research or investigative findings, issue recommendations to assist in informing the development of model codes, and provide information to

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Windstorm Impact Reduction Act of 2004/s:204/ss:b/p:1

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall be responsible for carrying out research and development to improve model building codes, voluntary standards, and best practices for the design, construction, and retrofit of buildings, structures, and lifelines.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: National Institute of Standards and Technology

text.#text: In addition to the lead agency responsibilities described under

header.#text: National Institute of Standards and Technology

text.#text: engineering and the atmospheric sciences to improve the understanding of the behavior of windstorms and their impact on buildings, structures, and lifelines; and
economic and social factors influencing windstorm risk reduction measures.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall support atmospheric sciences research to improve the understanding of the behavior of windstorms and their impact on buildings, structures, and lifelines.

text.#text: the development of risk assessment tools and effective mitigation techniques;
public outreach and information dissemination; and
promotion of the adoption of windstorm preparedness and mitigation measures, including for households, businesses, and communities, consistent with the Agency’s all-hazards approach; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , to promote the implementation of research results and promote better building practices within the building design and construction industry, including architects, engineers, contractors, builders, and inspectors.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: National Institute of Standards and Technology
